poem:
**The Pores of Forty**  

Now that I am forty, makeup  
has turned traitor.  
It conspires with time  
to settle into the tiny ledges,  
cracks in the landscape of my face.  
Morning routines now sacred rites,  
balms and oils anointed with the hopes  
that memory softens,  
and mirrors forgive.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Now I’ve hit my 40s, makeup settles into my pores. Why? Our skin tends to change every decade or so. In your 40s, it becomes drier due to hormonal fluctuations and might lose volume due to slower collagen production – across all genders. It’s worth getting the skincare basics in place now for the decade ahead. Start with a cleanser each morning; if your skin feels tight after you wash it, try a cream, balm or oil-based". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
